snippet: For the 13th edition of the performance-focused biennial in New York, the artist Ryan McNamara has created a melange of dance choreography and musical references featuring a disorienting surprise for attendees.
abstract: For the 13th edition of the performance-focused biennial in New York, the artist Ryan McNamara has created a melange of dance choreography and musical references featuring a disorienting surprise for attendees.
lead_paragraph: The artist Ryan McNamara has become known in recent years for twisting uber-familiar pop references into his party-ready performance pieces. At Robert Wilson’s annual Watermill Benefit in 2011, he and a partner sang “Islands in the Stream,” the Dolly Parton-Kenny Rogers duet, while buried up to their necks in the ground. At the 2010 Whitney Biennial he transformed a corner of the museum into a karaoke jam called the Whitney Houston Biennial. McNamara billed “MEƎM: A Story Ballet About the Internet, the elaborate, multidancer piece he created for this year’s Performa festival as “a choreographic exploration of the online world as a space of engagement.”

headline.main: After Hours | At Performa, Ryan McNamara’s Pop-Rock Haunted House
